title: How to disprove Jesus' resurrection - Quora
tags: Jesus in the Old and New Testament

response.answer_text: You can disprove Jesus’ Resurrection in the same way that you can disprove time travel. When we discuss Jesus rising from death, no one is saying that it was a normal or natural occurrence. The Resurrection of Jesus is so noteworthy precisely because it’s so impossible. Imagine if scientists invented time-travel. Many people would be incredibly excited about it, because it’s something we all thought was impossible. We would delight to imagine all the possibilities it now provides to us. But of course, some would doubt that it’s real, because so many people before thought it was impossible. They would explain it away as a deception, a magic trick, or a scam. That’s how people reacted to Jesus’ Resurrection. Those that saw and believed were incredibly excited. They delighted to imagine all the possibilities. With death defeated and eternal life guaranteed, then we can use our earthly lives entirely differently. We can sacrifice our earthly lives for the benefit of others, because even if we die here, we’ll live forever with Jesus. Death is no longer the enemy; it’s merely a point of transition. But of course, some doubted that Jesus’ Resurrection was real, because so many people thought it was impossible. They tried to explain Jesus’ Resurrection away as a deception, a magic trick, or a scam. They still do. If someone is determined not to believe, there’s nothing you can do to make them believe. Even if you used your time machine to bring the skeptic a long-lost object from their past, they could explain it away by saying it’s a clever duplicate. After all, which is easier, to duplicate an object from someone’s past or to invent time travel? Even if you took them on a trip in the time machine, they could explain the trip away as a drug-induced hypnotic event, or a clever use of virtual reality, or a mind-altering sonic technology. After all, aren’t all of those options easier than inventing time travel? If someone doesn’t want to believe, they won’t. But if someone is open-minded, then you have hope. Jesus’ disciples did not believe He had risen from death, at first. When the women who went to the empty tomb reported that Jesus had risen from death, the disciples scoffed. As honest skeptics, they didn’t understand how someone who was clearly dead could be alive again. They remained skeptical until Jesus appeared to them directly. Not only did Jesus appear, but He let them examine His body to see for sure that He had died and was alive again. Jesus showed them the scars in His hands and feet, as well as the spear-wound that punctured His heart on the Cross. They could verify for themselves that He was alive, despite dying before their eyes. The evidence was so strong that the disciples of Jesus gave their lives to transform the Roman Empire with the message of Jesus. They willingly embraced execution to spread the news that Jesus is alive, death is defeated, and God has opened the way for every person to be with Him in Heaven, if you want to come. They saw the impossible happen. Jesus defeated death. Jesus claimed to be God, then did what only God could do. They believed — because of the evidence. This is the same Jesus who invites you to experience Him today. Jesus never asks you for blind faith in things you can’t experience. He gives you His Word in the Bible, inviting you to taste and see. Test His wisdom, explore His philosophy, live life as He commands, and watch what happens. Further, when you bow knee and accept Jesus as your King, He fills you with His Spirit. He gives you instant, immediate access to Him. That’s what prayer is. He not only listens and answers your prayers, but He also speaks back. God is active. He works in your life, He speaks into your life, He transforms your life. The same power that rose Jesus from the grave lives inside everyone who chooses to follow Jesus. And that power is active. The truth often offends our expectations. Every paradigm-shifting scientific discovery meets incredible resistance upon its unveiling. Even Charles Darwin, today the darling of the scientific community, faced stiff opposition for his entire life from the majority of the scientists of his day. People who set their minds on one way of viewing the world do not embrace change easily — especially if they have to admit that they were wrong to do so. But the true scientific mindset embraces new ideas — especially paradigm-shifting ideas. Science, as a discipline of investigation, relies on the premise that the universe is filled with knowledge we don’t yet know. There is far more out there to be discovered than we have yet uncovered. That’s the joy of experimentation, discovery, and advancement. Thus, when the true scientific mindset encounters Darwin’s claims, it does not respond “That’s impossible.” Instead, it says “Interesting. Tell me why you believe that.” Likewise, when the true scientific mindset encounters the claim of Jesus’ Resurrection, the response is not “That’s impossible.” Instead, it responds “That would change everything I thought I knew. That’s exciting. Tell me more.” This is one of the reasons why such a vast number of leading scientists believe in God. James Tour, one of the world’s leading biologists and nano-scientists, put it this way: “I build molecules for a living. I can’t begin to tell you how difficult that job is. I stand in awe of God because of what he has done through his creation. My faith has been increased through my research. Only a rookie who knows nothing about science would say science takes away from faith. If you really study science, it will bring you closer to God.” (Adams, C., “Leading Nanoscientist Builds Big Faith,” Baptist Standard, 15 March 2002.) Or as Sir Francis Bacon declared: ”A little science estranges a man from God. A lot of science brings him back.”

Q: Is it possible to disprove Jesus’ resurrection? Hello, Billbobjoe1234, and welcome to Quora! We can’t even prove that Jesus was crucified (or, for that matter, that he was even a real person who actually lived in the first place), so how in the world would you ever expect anybody to prove that he didn’t come back to lifer after supposedly living and being crucified? I mean, it’s like asking if anybody can prove that Atlantis didn’t sink into the ocean when nobody has even been able to prove that Atlantis wasn’t just a wholly fictional place to begin with. Cart before the horse, dude. Having said that, what would it even matter? Let’s say, for the sake of argument, that we actually could prove that Jesus lived and that he was crucified and that nobody could prove that he wasn’t resurrected? Where would that get you? Do you somehow think that the inability to prove something false somehow makes it even slightly more likely that the thing in question is true if you don’t have any independent evidence of its truth? That’s not how logic works, and if the best argument you have for your religious beliefs is, “nobody can prove they are false,” then you might as well just give up right now. But, hey — let’s throw logic out the window and imagine just for a second that the fact that nobody can disprove the resurrection of a possibly fictitious character somehow does provide evidence that that character was resurrected, just like it says in the Bible. So what? A man was crucified, apparently died much sooner than most people in that situation, was taken down and buried in an above ground tomb, and was then reported being alive days later. And? History is filled with people who were declared dead only to “come back to life” days later (sometimes, unfortunately, after having been placed in a coffin and buried in the ground). Do you think they had medical examiners or coroners 2000 years ago? Any way to check for brain activity? Even if you assume that Jesus somehow “rose from the dead,” that still wouldn’t prove that, say, he was the literal Son of God or that he took upon himself all our sins or that we can somehow gain eternal salvation by believing in him. Seriously, though — there are many ancient stories that describe supernatural events that we can’t prove are impossible. But since when is that mere fact alone actually justification for believing in them?  Note: My former Quora blog "Common Sense Atheism" has now been converted into a "Space" at Common Sense Atheism.
